results.headline: A Family’s Growing Pains, Both Adolescent and Adult
results.summary_short: “Whole New Thing,” a minutely observed family drama, is the rare film in which the actors playing parents and child feel biologically connected.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Whole New Thing

results.headline: Back to the (Double) Feature
results.summary_short: “Grindhouse” is soaked in bloody nostalgia for the cheesy, disreputable pleasures of an older form of movie entertainment.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Grindhouse

results.headline: A Teenager’s Quiet Trek Toward Revenge
results.summary_short: Gently and quietly told, “Daratt” (“Dry Season”) is an unassumingly political work that unfolds with the simplicity of a parable and the gravity of a Bible story.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Daratt

results.headline: Released From Prison, but Not From His Past
results.summary_short: The stunning “Los Muertos” plunges the viewer directly into its protagonist’s world.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Los Muertos

results.headline: Table Tennis as Extreme Sport
results.summary_short: “Ping Pong” is probably the most extravagant celebration of a childhood game ever committed to film.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ping Pong

results.headline: At War With Absurdity
results.summary_short: “G. I. Jesús” may be a mixed bag, but it is so impressive in so many ways that it demands to be taken seriously.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of G.I. Jesus

results.headline: Under the Spanish Moss, a River Runs Blood Red
results.summary_short: The only remotely notable thing about this particular jumble of boos, bangs and door creaks is that it tries to wed the horror trend with the heated-up God market.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Reaping

results.headline: Star Dog Loses His Way but Still Leads Humans
results.summary_short: In “Firehouse Dog” a pampered Hollywood pooch trades his movie-star lifestyle for a run-down firehouse sadly in need of a mascot.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Firehouse Dog

results.headline: Hammer, Nails, Dry Rot and Do-It-Yourself Trouble
results.summary_short: The rapper Ice Cube returns to the multiplex with “Are We Done Yet?,” a feeble fable of better parenting through home improvement.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Are We Done Yet?

results.headline: Bedding That Nice Nazi, and Other Wartime Perils
results.summary_short: Paul Verhoeven’s “Black Book” encompasses the best and very worst of its director’s signature pulp brutalism, which means it’s pretty much a hoot.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Black Book

results.headline: Whereabouts in Watts? Where Poetry Meets Chaos
results.summary_short: “Killer of Sheep,” largely hidden from view for three decades, is an American masterpiece, independent to the bone.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Killer of Sheep

results.headline: Shifty Wedding Crashers: Secrets From the Past
results.summary_short: “After the Wedding” is a modern creation with a classic theme involving haves and have-nots, bloodlines and family ties.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of After the Wedding

results.headline: The Modern Mating Game Through a Low-Key Lens
results.summary_short: “Summer in Berlin” is a pointedly unglamorous slice of life that could be set in any urban neighborhood where real estate prices haven’t gone through the roof.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Summer in Berlin

results.headline: Higher Self-Esteem Through Robbery
results.summary_short: “The Lookout” is a new version of a very old story: A nobody falls in with scuzzball crooks who make him feel like somebody.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Lookout

results.headline: Live From the Rink, It’s Will Ferrell on Ice
results.summary_short: With “Blades of Glory,” Will Ferrell and Jon Heder stake an early claim to being the comedy couple of the year.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blades of Glory

results.headline: From Immigration to Anarchy
results.summary_short: The meat-and-potatoes style of “Sacco and Vanzetti” seems less a failure of imagination than a means of putting in the foreground its intriguing subject matter.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sacco & Vanzetti

results.headline: Crumpled Manhood Revisited
results.summary_short: Imagine an entire film infected with hangdog sensibility, unrelieved by humor or narrative interest, and you have “The Hawk Is Dying.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Hawk is Dying

results.headline: In a Trance Where Strobes Flash and the Techno Beat Pulses
results.summary_short: If you’re looking for a documentary about the electronic music scene filled with historical lectures, performance clips and talking heads, “Headspace” isn’t for you.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Headspace

results.headline: Those Arias, That Tragedy, in Xhosa
results.summary_short: No one can know whether Bizet would have approved of the movie musical “U-Carmen e-Khayelitsha.” But you suspect that he would have admired the filmmakers’ gall.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of U-Carmen

results.headline: Forget the Eyes. The Teeth and Tongues Are Worse.
results.summary_short: “The Hills Have Eyes 2” is essentially a catalog of transgressive images, lighted and edited like a heavy-metal video.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Hills Have Eyes 2
